lines.content: - This project used the Cursor AI tool (GPT-based) as a pair-programmer to accelerate documentation and code-quality work. All AI-assisted changes were reviewed, edited, and validated by a human maintainer before being committed.
- Documentation: drafting and tightening code comments and JavaDoc documentation.
- Code quality: small refactors that do not change behavior (e.g., explicit imports, final classes for commands, private constructor for utility classes, improved encapsulation, clearer messages).
- Feature support: improving the search experience (partial/phrase/typo-tolerant matching) and adding focused unit tests that describe and verify the expected behavior.
- Build/dev ergonomics: suggestion to scope JVM assertions to packages for safer testing without affecting unrelated modules.
- Human-in-the-loop: every suggestion was inspected and, when appropriate, edited by a human before merging.
- Verification: code compiled and tests were run locally using the Gradle wrapper (./gradlew test). New tests were added to cover the BetterSearch behavior.
- Minimal surface area: AI was provided only with repository context necessary for the task. No credentials or secrets were shared with the tool, and no generated secrets were committed.
- Licensing and originality: the assistant did not paste external, license-incompatible code. All changes are either original or transformations of existing project code.
- Search: enhancement of TaskList.find to support partial matches, quoted phrases, and limited typo tolerance (edit distance ≤ 1 with sensible length guards).
- Tests: TaskListFindTest covering partial, phrase, typo tolerance, and multi-term AND behavior.

- Code quality: final command classes, @FunctionalInterface on Command, private ctor + final for FileParser, explicit imports in Parser, small clarity and robustness improvements in exceptions and task model classes.
- Build and test with the wrapper:
- Java/JavaFX: the repo uses the Gradle wrapper and JavaFX 17; the wrapper ensures a reproducible build environment.
- AI suggestions can be imperfect. Tests cover primary and new behaviors, but additional edge cases may surface; please file issues if you find any.
- AI-generated text may have been further edited for clarity and accuracy; final responsibility for the code and documentation rests with project maintainers.
This project used the Cursor AI tool to assist with documentation and for betterhelop during development.

Penguin is a friendly task-list chatbot you can run in the terminal or as a JavaFX app. It supports adding todos, deadlines and events, listing, marking, deleting, saving to disk, and a powerful BetterSearch to find items quickly.
- Build and run tests: `./gradlew clean test`
Data file location: `data/penguin.txt` (created on first run).
- All terms must match somewhere in the task text
- Partial word matches for terms ≥ 3 chars (e.g., `book` matches `booking`)
- Quoted phrase matches exact text (e.g., `"team meeting"`)
- Small-typo tolerance for terms ≥ 4 chars (edit distance ≤ 1)
- Tasks are saved to `data/penguin.txt` automatically when exiting.
- Indexes shown by `list` are 1-based; use those numbers with `mark`, `unmark`, and `delete`.
- If the app doesn’t start, ensure Java 17 is selected (Gradle wrapper manages the rest).
- If the data file path is missing, it will be created on first save.
- Build and run tests: `./gradlew clean test`
// Match your JDK version. If you’re on Java 21, use 21.x; if on Java 17, use 17.x.
version = '17.0.16'   // or '17.0.10' if you’re strictly on Java 17
// IMPORTANT: point to a tiny bootstrap (Launcher) that calls Application.launch(...)
// Enable JVM assertions only for the model package (and subpackages)
// You can keep Shadow, but GUI fat-jars can be tricky.
// Prefer Gradle’s run/distribution for JavaFX. If you keep it:
// Disable Gradle's default global assertions; enable selectively via jvmArgs below
// Enable JVM assertions only for the model package during tests
// Not needed for GUI, but harmless to keep
// Enable JVM assertions only for the model package during 'gradle run'

Penguin is a friendly task-list chatbot you can run in the terminal or as a JavaFX app. It supports adding todos, deadlines and events, listing, marking, deleting, saving to disk, and a powerful BetterSearch to find items quickly.
- Build and run tests: `./gradlew clean test`
Data file location: `data/penguin.txt` (created on first run).
- All terms must match somewhere in the task text
- Partial word matches for terms ≥ 3 chars (e.g., `book` matches `booking`)
- Quoted phrase matches exact text (e.g., `"team meeting"`)
- Small-typo tolerance for terms ≥ 4 chars (edit distance ≤ 1)
- Tasks are saved to `data/penguin.txt` automatically when exiting.
- Indexes shown by `list` are 1-based; use those numbers with `mark`, `unmark`, and `delete`.
- If the app doesn’t start, ensure Java 17 is selected (Gradle wrapper manages the rest).
- If the data file path is missing, it will be created on first save.
- Build and run tests: `./gradlew clean test`

* Coordinates the execution of the Penguin application.

*
  • Parsing input into {@link Command} objects via {@link Parser}.

*
  • Executing commands and showing results back to the user.

*
  • Persisting tasks and shutting down gracefully when the user exits.
/** The parser that interprets raw user input into {@link Command} objects. */

* Exception thrown when a user provides an invalid task index.

*
  • The index is out of bounds (negative or greater than the last task).

*

* The error message is constructed to be user-friendly, showing either
* the raw invalid input string or the invalid one-based index.
public final class InvalidIndexException extends PenguinException {

* @param idx the zero-based index that is invalid

* This exception provides feedback on the expected format of the command input,
* making it easier for users to correct their input.
public final class MissingArgumentException extends PenguinException {
* Constructs a new {@code MissingArgumentException} with a message that
* specifies the expected format of the command input.
* @param expected a description of the correct or expected command format
* Base exception type for all custom exceptions in the Penguin application.
* Extends {@link Exception} to allow specific, meaningful error handling
* within the application while preserving standard Java exception behavior.
* All application-specific exceptions should subclass {@code PenguinException}.
public abstract class PenguinException extends Exception {
* Constructs a new {@code PenguinException} with the specified detail message.
* @param message the detail message describing the cause of the exception
* Constructs a new {@code PenguinException} with the specified detail message and cause.
* @param cause   the cause of this exception
* Constructs a new {@code PenguinException} with the specified cause.
* @param cause the cause of this exception
* Thrown to indicate that the user entered a command that does not exist
* or is not recognized by the Penguin application.
* This exception provides feedback to the user by including the unrecognized
public final class UnknownCommandException extends PenguinException {
* Constructs a new {@code UnknownCommandException} for the given command.
* @param cmd the unrecognized command entered by the user
super("It's chill but what do you mean lol: \"" + String.valueOf(cmd) + "\".");

return List.of(); // return empty list if something fails

*
  • If the file exists, it is overwritten.

public static boolean writeLinesToFile(String filePath, List<String> lines) {
return false; // signal failure to caller
* The {@code Parser} is responsible for translating raw user input
* strings into {@link Command} objects that can be executed.

*
  • Splitting into command keyword and argument string.

*
  • Dispatching to the correct {@link Command} subclass based on the keyword.

*
  • Enforcing required arguments for commands like {@code mark}, {@code unmark}, and {@code delete}.
* Parses a raw user input string into a {@link Command}.

*
  • {@code mark } – Mark a task as done.

*
  • {@code unmark } – Mark a task as not done.
* @throws UnknownCommandException   if the command keyword is not recognized or if input is null/empty
* @throws MissingArgumentException  if a required argument is missing for commands that need one
public Command parse(String input) throws UnknownCommandException, MissingArgumentException {
// Assertion: after trimming, input should not be null (String#trim never returns null).
assert trimmed != null : "trimmed input unexpectedly null";
// Assertion: split must always produce at least one element.
assert parts.length >= 1 : "split on input produced empty parts array";
// Assertion: command keyword must never be blank here.
* Ensures that an argument string is present for commands that require one.
* @param c        the command to return if argument is valid
* @param arg      the argument string to check
* @param expected usage string for error reporting
* @return the provided command if argument is valid
* @throws MissingArgumentException if the argument is {@code null} or blank
private Command requireArgThen(Command c, String arg, String expected) throws MissingArgumentException {
// Assertion: 'expected' should never be null — it's a contract of this helper.
assert expected != null : "expected usage string cannot be null";
if (arg == null || arg.isBlank()) throw new MissingArgumentException(expected);
// Assertion: if we reached here, arg must be non-null and non-blank.
assert arg != null && !arg.isBlank() : "argument unexpectedly invalid after validation";

* @return a {@link CommandResult} containing the success message after adding the task
* @throws MissingArgumentException if the input is missing or does not match the expected format
public CommandResult execute(TaskList tasks) throws MissingArgumentException {
yield count >= 2; // must have at least 2 slashes
throw new MissingArgumentException("Invalid format. Expected: " + expectedUsage(type));
* Represents a command that signals the program to exit.

* Use the static factory methods {@link #of(String)} for normal results and

/** Whether this result signals that the program should exit. */

* Returns the message associated with this command result.
* Returns whether this result indicates program termination.
* @return {@code true} if the command signals exit; {@code false} otherwise
* Creates a non-exit {@code CommandResult} with the given message.
* Creates an exit {@code CommandResult} with the given message.

* Parses a single line into a concrete {@link Task}. The following storage formats are supported:

*
  • Pipes may be surrounded by arbitrary whitespace.

*
  • The "done" flag accepts {@code 1} / {@code 0} (and {@code true}/{@code false} for marking done).

*
  • Event timestamps are expected as ISO-like strings; the method does not parse them here—strings are passed through to {@link Event}.
* @param line   the raw line from storage
* @param nextId the zero-based id to assign to the created task
* @return a {@link Task} instance if parsing succeeds; {@code null} if the line is ignorable/invalid for non-Event types
* @throws IllegalArgumentException if an Event line does not contain both start and end (minimum 5 parts)

* - Matches if all query terms match the task text, where a term matches if:
*   - it is a quoted phrase present as a substring, OR
*   - it is a single token that is a substring of any word (partial match), OR
*   - it is within 1 edit (typo tolerance) of any word in the task text.
*   - query = book → matches "read a book" and also "booking" (partial)
*   - query = proj Aug → matches tasks containing both tokens (in any order)
* The numbering in the result corresponds to original task indices (1-based).
return new StringBuilder("Gimme something to search for, bro.");
return new StringBuilder("No matches found, bro. Try different keywords.");
StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder("Here’s what I found:\n");
private static boolean tokenMatches(String normHay, String token) {
if (normHay.contains(token)) return true; // direct substring across the whole text
// Partial match: token must be reasonably long, and match inside a word
if (token.length() >= MIN_PARTIAL && w.length() >= MIN_PARTIAL && w.contains(token)) return true;
// Typo tolerance: both sides reasonably long and within 1 edit
if (token.length() >= MIN_TYPO_LEN && w.length() >= MIN_TYPO_LEN && isEditDistanceAtMostOne(w, token)) return true;
private static boolean isEditDistanceAtMostOne(String a, String b) {
else if (la > lb) { i++; }            // deletion in a

* A {@link Task} representing an event with a start and end date/time.
